an3.133:4.1: “Mendicants, a warrior with three factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an3.133:4.3: He’s a long-distance shooter, a marksman, one who shatters large objects.
an3.133:4.4: A warrior with these three factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an3.133:4.5: In the same way, a mendicant with three factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.
an3.133:4.8: They’re a long-distance shooter, a marksman, and one who shatters large objects.
an3.133:5.1: And how is a mendicant a long-distance shooter?
an3.133:5.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with proper wisdom:
an3.133:5.3: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an3.133:5.4: They truly understand any kind of feeling at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all feeling—with proper wisdom:
an3.133:5.5: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an3.133:5.6: They truly understand any kind of perception at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all perception—with proper wisdom:
an3.133:5.7: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an3.133:5.8: They truly understand any kind of choices at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all choices—with proper wisdom:
an3.133:5.9: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an3.133:5.10: They truly understand any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with proper wisdom:
an3.133:5.11: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an3.133:5.12: That’s how a mendicant is a long-distance shooter.
an3.133:6.1: And how is a mendicant a marksman?
an3.133:6.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ …
an3.133:6.5: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
an3.133:6.6: That’s how a mendicant is a marksman.
an3.133:7.1: And how does a mendicant shatter large objects?
an3.133:7.2: It’s when a mendicant shatters the great mass of ignorance.
an3.133:7.3: That’s how a mendicant shatters large objects.
an3.133:7.4: A mendicant with these three factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.”
